column4: I need some help. I am trying to install Ubuntu 10.04 64 bit on an AMD64 computer, yet I don't seem to understand partitioning for it. I do not want to erase my entire hard drive.
I had 32 bit on my desktop, and it's install process was great. I do not know how to partition this one correctly to not screw it up.
I know this. I dont... *Waits*
My RAM is 3 GB. I shall make a 6 gig Swap file.
And why try zfs?
do you want to overwrite the 32-bit Ubuntu installation with the 64-bit Ubuntu installation?
well even if you have to manually partition, the process is not that hairy
but there should be a 3-radio-button list where the options are the equivalent of: 1. Install Ubuntu alongside other operating systems, 2. Blow everything else away, and 3. Manually partition
weird. well, specify partitions manually. Right-click the biggest the NTFS partition, select change, and change the size of the partition
that must be why the installer didn't have an option to install alongside other operating systems
if you exit the installer and make sure the NTFS partition is not mounted (disk utility or just type mount at a prompt) you can see if gparted will let you resize it

disclaimer: I'm not an op or official Ubuntu support or anything. I've been in this channel for about an hour. I came here to ask a question about bridging wireless networks, but at this point I don't think this is the right place for it.
try rebooting and run the installer directly instead of live
hehe that looks bad
does your partition have some kind of transparent encryption?
I doubt it's your actual BIOS, but I would keep it around
I really think you should try to resize the big 280GiB partition
I see you found Gparted. If you make sure it's unmounted, even Gparted won't do it?
see how it says mount point and it has text there? that text should not be there
when that column is empty for sda2, try to resize it

http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=487300 it's a little dated, but this thread says try chkdsk /f on the partition in safe mode then reboot windows a couple of times to let the scans run before Windows attempts to load  the OS off the partition
